metadata.title: Robinson R44
aws::graph::propositions: # Robinson R44 Safety Analysis and Airworthiness Directives
The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) conducted a preliminary analysis of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) accident database.
The ATSB analysis found that 15% of accidents in the United States involving Robinson R44 helicopters had post-crash fires.
The ATSB data did not consider which type of fuel tanks were fitted in the Robinson R44 helicopters.
The ATSB report mentioned four fatal accidents involving Robinson R44 helicopters fitted with bladder-type tanks.
The four fatal accidents involving Robinson R44 helicopters with bladder-type tanks did not involve post-accident fires as far as the ATSB knew.
The ATSB recommended that the Australian Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) take further action to urge Robinson R44 owners to fit bladder-type tanks.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is the governing body in the United States, the country where Robinson R44 helicopters are manufactured.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) had not mandated the retrofit of bladder-type tanks for Robinson R44 helicopters.
FAA directives would normally be followed in countries like Australia.
The Australian Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) issued Australian-specific airworthiness directive AD/R44/23.
The Australian Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) airworthiness directive AD/R44/23 grounded Robinson R44 helicopters that had not yet been upgraded with bladder-type tanks.
The grounding of non-upgraded Robinson R44 helicopters in Australia took effect on 30 April 2013.

The ATSB analysis found that 15% of accidents in the United States involving Robinson R44 helicopters had post-crash fires.
The ATSB data did not consider which type of fuel tanks were fitted in the Robinson R44 helicopters.

The four fatal accidents involving Robinson R44 helicopters with bladder-type tanks did not involve post-accident fires as far as the ATSB knew.

complement.value: no post-accident fires with bladder-type tanks

statements.value: The ATSB recommended that the Australian Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) take further action to urge Robinson R44 owners to fit bladder-type tanks.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is the governing body in the United States, the country where Robinson R44 helicopters are manufactured.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) had not mandated the retrofit of bladder-type tanks for Robinson R44 helicopters.

complement.value: had not mandated bladder-type tank retrofit

statements.value: FAA directives would normally be followed in countries like Australia.

complement.value: normally followed in countries like Australia

statements.value: The Australian Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) issued Australian-specific airworthiness directive AD/R44/23.
The Australian Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) airworthiness directive AD/R44/23 grounded Robinson R44 helicopters that had not yet been upgraded with bladder-type tanks.
The grounding of non-upgraded Robinson R44 helicopters in Australia took effect on 30 April 2013.

text:
Preliminary analysis by the ATSB of the NTSB's accident database found a similar statistic, with 15% of accidents in the US involving R44 helicopters having post-crash fires.

Although the data did not consider which type of fuel tanks were fitted, the report mentioned four fatal accidents to the R44 fitted with bladder-type tanks, but as far as they knew, did not involve a post-accident fire. The ATSB recommended that the Australian Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) take further action to urge R44 owners to fit bladder-type tanks. The FAA, the governing body in the country of manufacture whose directives would normally be followed in other countries like Australia, had not mandated the retrofit; CASA therefore issued Australian-specific airworthiness directive AD/R44/23, grounding R44 aircraft on 30 April 2013 that had not yet been upgraded.
